content.question:
Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the functions defined by <math alttext="f of x, equals, the fraction with numerator 1 minus, cosine x, and denominator x squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g of x, equals, x squared, times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction 1 over x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="h of x, equals, the fraction with numerator sine x, and denominator x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="x is not equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. All of the following inequalities are true for <math alttext="x is not equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the inequalities can be used with the squeeze theorem to find the limit of the function as <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> approaches 0 ?
<math alttext="one third, times, open parenthesis, 1 minus x squared, close parenthesis, is less than or equal to, f of x, which is less than or equal to, one half" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="negative, x squared, is less than or equal to, g of x, which is less than or equal to, x squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>≤</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="negative, the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator the absolute value of x, end fraction, is less than or equal to, h of x, which is less than or equal to, the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator the absolute value of x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>≤</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 1.8: Determining Limits Using the Squeeze Theorem

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Confirm whether hypotheses or conditions of a selected definition, theorem, or test have been satisfied.
